content.description:
If you climb Wimps, just keep going and do this one too.

The route is steeper than "Wimps.." but has actual holds! Follow a line of bolts up and to the right of the large Oak growing on the face. There is an older set of bolts that often does not have webbing, or the webbing there is dangerous. Be kind, bring webbing and a rap ring.
content.protection: 4 bolts, sling for tree, webbing for anchor.
content.location: From the top of "Wimps Are People Too", continue up and to the right of the large tree. Older rap bolts.

content.description:
A low angle start gradually gets steeper with holdless  but positive smearing through 3 bolts. Pass over the large step (optional cam here) and past one more bolt to the belay.

There is a second pitch, quite fun to do, called "You Round Table Guys".
content.protection: 3 bolts, optional finger sized cam, bolted belay.
content.location: From the 'Plumas County' road sign, head up the dirty gully to a large ledge and a bolted belay. From the ledge, the second route to the left. All the routes on Plumas Slab start at this belay.

content.description:
Originally rated PG13, the consensus among the few who have climbed it in the past years is R. The line remains dirty, can be wet for months, and is a challenge at 10.a.

All of that said, this is a really good line, almost solid smearing w/few 'holds'.

Head straight up from the belay towards the mini roof/step. First bolt is 15'+, and it is heady pulling over the step. Pass 2 more bolts ad then be prepared for 20' of unrelenting 5.10 smear-fest. Just don't think about the fall potential, the roof below, of the dirt and munge.
content.location: From the 'Plumas County' road sign, head up the dirty gully to a large ledge and a bolted belay. From the ledge, the first route to the left. All the routes on Plumas Slab start at this belay.
